   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis/leukocytosis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also
   possibly due to pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors
   and IVF bolus to support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so
   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   Octreotide discontinued per hepatology.  Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda
   12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue cipro/clinda for now
   - Peritoneal infection appears adequately treated, given recent para
   with WBC 86 (<250).
   - Leukocytosis: Unclear source at present
sputum, blood, urine cultures
   are pending. C. diff has been negative x 2.  As pt has been clinically
   improving over same period, will continue to monitor and keep only
   Cipro/Clinda for now.
   - Broaden abx if pt spikes a fever or decompensate (add back
   Vanc/Zosyn).
   - Continuing Midodrine
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia
   - will try to discontinue lines, as patient improves clinically.
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - results of recent paracentesis do not suggest on-going intraabdominal
   infection.
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP. All sedation off
   since [**12-19**].
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal 0.5-1L negative today
   - 5pm lytes
   - continue 100mg daily spironolactone
   - will check an SBT with ABG before and after
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome. Currently resolved.
   - Will continue free water flushes at 300cc q6h.
    - pm electrolyte check
   -  diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone.
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Improved.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, additional AMS w/u if no improvement with tx of
   hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures
   - Checking direct bilirubin today ([**12-25**]), as pt w. decr HCT and
   increased total bili, to rule out hemolysis.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   - culture of infection
   - telemetry
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   . Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen.
   Prolactin elevated. Pt has a history of painful gynecomastia, per pt
   girlfriend.
   - cont tamoxifen
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Resolved. Redose meds.
   Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be due to sepsis which
   resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x 2 days (during this
   hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5 [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely
   due to aggressive diuresis in last several days plus IV contrast load
   for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given
   Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - d/c albumin
   - monitor UOP closely
   - d/c octreotide
   - diuresis as above
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: D5W today, replete electrolytes.  TPN.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, SQH
   Access: R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son

   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis, possibly due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The patient was intubated in the emergency department (ED) due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure.

Current medical issues:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high white blood cell count and is suspected to have sepsis due to SBP.
3. Peritonitis: The patient has a diagnosis of peritonitis, which is likely due to SBP.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient has a high sodium level, which is likely due to insensitivity to aldosterone.
5. Altered mental status: The patient has a decreased level of consciousness, which is likely due to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy.
6. Anemia: The patient has a low hematocrit level, which is likely due to chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease and acute blood loss anemia.
7. Hepatitis C cirrhosis: The patient has a history of hepatitis C and cirrhosis, which is likely contributing to his liver dysfunction.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which is likely due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease.
9. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is likely due to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and SBP.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may develop further respiratory failure if his underlying lung disease worsens or if he develops pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient may develop further sepsis if his underlying infection worsens or if he develops a new infection.
3. Peritonitis: The patient may develop further peritonitis if his underlying infection worsens or if he develops a new infection.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient may develop further hypernatremia if his sodium level is not properly managed.
5. Altered mental status: The patient may develop further altered mental status if his underlying liver disease worsens or if he develops a new infection.
6. Anemia: The patient may develop further anemia if his underlying liver disease worsens or if he develops a new bleeding episode.
7. Hepatitis C cirrhosis: The patient may develop further liver dysfunction if his underlying hepatitis C cirrhosis worsens.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient may develop further thrombocytopenia if his underlying liver disease worsens or if he develops a new bleeding episode.
9. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient may develop further non-anion gap metabolic acidosis if his underlying liver disease worsens or if he develops a new infection.

Management:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to support the patient's respiratory status.
2. Continue antibiotics to treat the patient's underlying infection.
3. Manage the patient's hypernatremia with free water flushes and diuretics.
4. Manage the patient's altered mental status with lactulose and rifaximin.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia with frequent blood tests and transfusions as needed.
6. Manage the patient's hepatitis C cirrhosis with antiviral therapy and liver transplantation if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's non-anion gap metabolic acidosis with frequent ABG tests and adjust his management accordingly.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his underlying medical issues.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis/leukocytosis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also
   possibly due to pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors
   and IVF bolus to support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so
   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   Octreotide discontinued per hepatology.  Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda
   12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue cipro/clinda for now, continue for 3 week course
   - Discontinue Midodrine to determine if pressures hold
   - Peritoneal infection appears adequately treated, given recent para
   with WBC 86 (<250).
   - Leukocytosis: Unclear source at present
sputum, blood, urine cultures
   are pending. C. diff has been negative x 2.  As pt has been clinically
   improving over same period, will continue to monitor and keep only
   Cipro/Clinda for now.
   - Broaden abx if pt spikes a fever or decompensate (add back
   Vanc/Zosyn).
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia
   - will try to discontinue lines, as patient improves clinically.
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - results of recent paracentesis do not suggest on-going intraabdominal
   infection.
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Patient delirious since prior to extubation, unclear cause.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, additional AMS w/u if no improvement with tx of
   hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP. All sedation off
   since [**12-19**].
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - Diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal -1L negative today
   - 5pm lytes
   - continue 100mg daily spironolactone
   - will check an SBT with ABG before and after
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome. Currently resolved.  Now hyponatremic.
   - Will continue free water flushes at 300cc q6h.
    - pm electrolyte check
   -  diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures
   - Checking direct bilirubin today ([**12-25**]), as pt w. decr HCT and

   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function

 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis/leukocytosis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also
   possibly due to pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors
   and IVF bolus to support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so
   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   Octreotide discontinued per hepatology.  Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda
   12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue cipro/clinda for now, continue for 3 week course
   - Discontinue Midodrine to determine if pressures hold
   - Peritoneal infection appears adequately treated, given recent para
   with WBC 86 (<250).
   - Leukocytosis: Unclear source at present
sputum, blood, urine cultures
   are pending. C. diff has been negative x 2.  As pt has been clinically
   improving over same period, will continue to monitor and keep only
   Cipro/Clinda for now.
   - Broaden abx if pt spikes a fever or decompensate (add back
   Vanc/Zosyn).
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia
   - will try to discontinue lines, as patient improves clinically.
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - results of recent paracentesis do not suggest on-going intraabdominal
   infection.
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Patient delirious since prior to extubation, unclear cause.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, additional AMS w/u if no improvement with tx of
   hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP. All sedation off
   since [**12-19**].
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - Diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal -1L negative today
   - 5pm lytes
   - continue 100mg daily spironolactone
   - will check an SBT with ABG before and after
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome. Currently resolved.  Now hyponatremic.
   - Will continue free water flushes at 300cc q6h.
    - pm electrolyte check
   -  diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures
   - Checking direct bilirubin today ([**12-25**]), as pt w. decr HCT and
   increased total bili, to rule out hemolysis.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   - culture of infection
   - telemetry
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   . Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen.
   Prolactin elevated. Pt has a history of painful gynecomastia, per pt
   girlfriend.
   - cont tamoxifen
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Resolved. Redose meds.
   Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be due to sepsis which
   resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x 2 days (during this
   hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5 [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely
   due to aggressive diuresis in last several days plus IV contrast load
   for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given
   Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - d/c albumin
   - monitor UOP closely
   - d/c octreotide
   - diuresis as above
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: D5W today, replete electrolytes.  TPN.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, SQH
   Access: R triple-lumen IJ, a-line

   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is not yet fully resolved, and there is a risk of recurrent sepsis, particularly with the ongoing peritonitis and potential for further infection.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and there is a risk of further respiratory decline, particularly with the ongoing acidosis and potential for further fluid overload.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver function is still impaired, and there is a risk of further hepatic encephalopathy, particularly with the ongoing hyperbilirubinemia and potential for further liver injury.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further anemia, particularly with the ongoing bleeding and potential for further blood loss.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further thrombocytopenia, particularly with the ongoing liver dysfunction and potential for further platelet destruction.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further hyperkalemia, particularly with the ongoing kidney dysfunction and potential for further potassium release.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further hypotension, particularly with the ongoing sepsis and potential for further vasodilation.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further fluid overload, particularly with the ongoing diuresis and potential for further fluid accumulation.
9. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further bleeding, particularly with the ongoing liver dysfunction and potential for further bleeding.
10. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is still not fully resolved, and there is a risk of further renal failure, particularly with the ongoing kidney dysfunction and potential for further kidney injury.

To mitigate these risks, the patient will require close monitoring and management of their respiratory, hepatic, and gastrointestinal functions, as well as continued treatment of their sepsis and anemia. The patient's family should be educated on the potential complications and the importance of close monitoring and follow-up care.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with Hepatitis C cirrhosis, varices, and a history of bloody stools. He was admitted with shortness of breath and abdominal pain, and was intubated in the emergency department. He was found to have Clostridium perfringens in his blood and peritoneal fluid with 17,000 white blood cells. He was extubated yesterday and has been delirious and encephalopathic. He has been experiencing large stool output and has a Coombs-positive anemia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 110/51 mmHg. He has a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96%. His lung sounds are clear, and he has mild pulmonary edema on chest X-ray.

The patient's laboratory results show acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. His liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels. His blood glucose level is elevated at 122 mg/dL.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Hypernatremia (high sodium)
2. Acute pain
3. Respiratory failure
4. Sepsis without organ dysfunction
5. Peritonitis
6. Anemia, chronic
7. Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss
8. Thrombocytopenia, chronic
9. Cirrhosis of the liver
10. Hepatitis
11. Metabolic acidosis

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Septic shock
2. Organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury or liver failure
3. Respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation
4. Hemorrhage or bleeding, secondary to coagulopathy
5. Infection, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection
6. Delirium or encephalopathy, worsening cognitive function
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
8. Sepsis-induced cardiovascular instability
9. Metabolic acidosis, leading to cardiac arrhythmias or decreased cardiac output
10. Coagulopathy, leading to bleeding or thrombosis

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
2. Treatment of hypernatremia with IV fluids
3. Pain management with IV medications
4. Respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
5. Antibiotics for suspected Clostridium perfringens infection
6. Consultation with hematology for anemia and thrombocytopenia
7. Monitoring of liver function tests and coagulation studies
8. Nutrition support with TPN and lipids
9. Glycemic control with insulin therapy
10. Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Sepsis/leukocytosis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also
   possibly due to pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors
   and IVF bolus to support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so
   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   Octreotide discontinued per hepatology.  Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda
   12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin
   - Continue cipro/clinda for now, continue for 3 week course
   - Discontinue Midodrine to determine if pressures hold
   - Peritoneal infection appears adequately treated, given recent para
   with WBC 86 (<250).
   - Leukocytosis: Unclear source at present
sputum, blood, urine cultures
   are pending. C. diff has been negative x 2.  As pt has been clinically
   improving over same period, will continue to monitor and keep only
   Cipro/Clinda for now.
   - Broaden abx if pt spikes a fever or decompensate (add back
   Vanc/Zosyn).
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia
   - will try to discontinue lines, as patient improves clinically.
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  WBC high but improved from
   prior, obtaining CT scan to further evaluate, as outlined above.
   - Cipro/Clinda as above
   - Abdomen continues to be significantly distended; holding
   Metoclopramide/Regla for now
   - f/u GI/Liver recs
   - f/u transplant surgery recs
   - results of recent paracentesis do not suggest on-going intraabdominal
   infection.
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4
   hepatic encephalopathy, given patient
s severe liver disease and rising
   bilirubin. Patient delirious since prior to extubation, unclear cause.
   - Titrate up Lactulose to 3 BMs daily.
   - Continue Rifaxamin
   - Can consider head CT, additional AMS w/u if no improvement with tx of
   hepatic encephalopathy.
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP. All sedation off
   since [**12-19**].
   - ABG and lactate daily (lactate down-trending now)
   - Diurese today with lasix 40mg, goal -1L negative today
   - 5pm lytes
   - continue 100mg daily spironolactone
   - will check an SBT with ABG before and after
   .
   Hypernatremia:  Likely insensitivity to Aldosterone vs. hepatorenal
   syndrome. Currently resolved.  Now hyponatremic.
   - Will continue free water flushes at 300cc q6h.
    - pm electrolyte check
   -  diuresis as above with lasix and spironolactone.
   .
   Anemia: Pt's recent baseline hematocrit appears to be ~25-30, and was
   21 on admission. Pt was noted to be guaiac positive on exam in ED, and
   had frank blood in NGT. Suspect that pt has chronic macrocytic anemia
   secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia
   from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer. No schistocytes on smear to
   indicate hemolysis, however INR more elevated than in the past, and
   thrombocytopenia is more pronounced. GI did an EGD to evaluate for UGIB
   cause and no bleeding source was found.  Pt was on pantoprazole bolus
   and octreotide gtt for likely variceal bleeding: d/c
d now as HCT
   stable.
   - Continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Daily coags and CBC; Transfuse as needed for falling Hct.
   - 2 units FFP prior to any procedures
   - Checking direct bilirubin today ([**12-25**]), as pt w. decr HCT and
   increased total bili, to rule out hemolysis.
   .
   Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: MELD on admission was 27, discriminate function
   was 61. On exam pt is jaundiced. LFT's similar to prior LFT's with the
   exception of bili, which is markedly elevated at 18. Reportedly the pt
   stopped drinking EtOH in [**Month (only) 11**]. Serum EtOH was negative.
   - F/u Hepatology recs
   - lactulose and Rifaximin
   - Hold nadolol for now given hypotension, pressor requirement
   .
   #. Tachycardia
 think likely due to pain component, as patient appears
   uncomfortable and thrashes about when tachycardic
   - fentanyl boluses prn
   - culture of infection
   - telemetry
   .
   Less Active Issues
   .
   . Gynecomastia:  Gynecomastia [**2-9**] liver failure and increased estrogen.
   Prolactin elevated. Pt has a history of painful gynecomastia, per pt
   girlfriend.
   - cont tamoxifen
   .
   Acute Renal Failure:  Resolved. Redose meds.
   Patient initially had elevated Cr, thought to be due to sepsis which
   resolved).  Pt
s creatinine has been rising again x 2 days (during this
   hospitalization, Cr 1.7 -> 0.8 -> today 1.5 [**12-19**]).  ARF most likely
   due to aggressive diuresis in last several days plus IV contrast load
   for CT abd.  However, hepatorenal syndrome is also a possibility, given
   Midodrine, Octreotide, Albumin.  Improved UOP [**12-21**].
   - F/u renal recs.
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - d/c albumin
   - monitor UOP closely
   - d/c octreotide
   - diuresis as above
   .
   Epistaxis:  ENT consulted, patient s/p bilateral packing.
   - cont Epistaxis precautions
   .
   Thrombocytopenia: Currently plts are 34, which is below baseline.
   Suspect that thrombocytopenia is due to poor synthetic function in the
   setting of liver disease. Pt has chronic epistaxis. Hemolysis is less
   likely.  Smear showed: no schistocytes, a few large platelets but many
   small platelets.  Likely bone marrow difficulty with production at the
   same time as it tries to increase production in the setting of platelet
   destruction.
   - Trend plts daily
   - Avoid heparin products in the setting of plt<100, GIB
   .
   Non-anion gap Metabolic Acidosis: Resolved. pH on ABG 7.29. Pt has a
   normal anion gap in the setting of chronic hyponatremia. Suspect
   acidosis is secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis,
   SBP.  s/p 2 units PRBC transfusion.
   - frequent ABG's
   - hold maintenance fluids to avoid worsening of acidosis
   - add on alk phos and CEA to ascitic fluid analysis given GI/Liver
   service's concern for perforation
   - f/u renal recs, likely no need for HD now
   .
   FEN: D5W today, replete electrolytes.  TPN.
   Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, SQH
   Access: R triple-lumen IJ, a-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with girlfriend)
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] GF and son
   Contact Info: Girlfriend [**Name (NI) 105**] [**Name (NI) 1309**]  cell: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9699**] home: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9771**]
   Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 5320**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9701**]
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   TPN w/ Lipids - [**2150-12-26**] 03:38 PM 77 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain and was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of CAP.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis/leukocytosis: The patient has a high WBC count and is suspected to have sepsis due to SBP and possibly pneumonia. He is being treated with antibiotics and pressors to support his blood pressure.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, likely due to insensitivity to aldosterone or hepatorenal syndrome. He is being treated with free water flushes and diuretics.
3. Anemia: The patient has a low hematocrit and is suspected to have chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleeding or bleeding ulcer.
4. Hepatitis C cirrhosis: The patient has a high MELD score and is jaundiced. He is being treated with lactulose and rifaximin.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count and is suspected to have thrombocytopenia due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease.
6. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient has a normal anion gap and is suspected to have acidosis secondary to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and SBP.

The patient is also being treated for other conditions, including:

1. Acute pain: The patient is being treated with analgesics and anticonvulsants.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is being treated with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
3. Peritonitis: The patient is being treated with antibiotics and peritoneal drainage.
4. Gynecomastia: The patient is being treated with tamoxifen.
5. Epistaxis: The patient is being treated with bilateral packing.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated in the emergency department (ED) due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure. His ABG indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator settings.
* Sepsis: The patient has a high white blood cell count (WBC) and is suspected to have sepsis due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, likely due to multi-factorial causes including hemolysis, increased retention of potassium, and decreased stool output.
* Anemia: The patient has a low hematocrit (HCT) and is suspected to have chronic macrocytic anemia secondary to liver disease, with superimposed acute blood loss anemia from variceal bleed or bleeding ulcer.
* Hepatitis C cirrhosis: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated bilirubin and transaminases.
* Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is elevated, likely due to pain and discomfort.
* Gynecomastia: The patient has a history of painful gynecomastia, which is likely due to liver failure and increased estrogen.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, likely due to aggressive diuresis and IV contrast load for CT abdomen.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, likely due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease.
* Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's pH is abnormal, likely due to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and SBP.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for sepsis and SBP.
* Diuresis: The patient is receiving diuretics to treat fluid overload and hyperkalemia.
* Pain management: The patient is receiving pain medication for tachycardia and discomfort.
* Antiviral therapy: The patient is receiving antiviral therapy for hepatitis C.
* Liver transplantation: The patient is being evaluated for liver transplantation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and death.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level can continue to rise, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and death.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
* Hepatitis C cirrhosis: The patient's liver disease can progress, leading to liver failure and death.
* Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia can worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and death.
* Gynecomastia: The patient's gynecomastia can worsen, leading to pain and discomfort.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's kidney function can worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease and death.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count can continue to decline, leading to bleeding complications.
* Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's pH can continue to decline, leading to multi-organ dysfunction and death.

The patient's clinical improvement will depend on the successful treatment of his underlying conditions, including sepsis, SBP, and liver disease. Close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical status will be necessary to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with cirrhosis, septic shock due to Clostridium perfringens, and delirious/delusional behavior. He is extubated and has intermittent hot flushes, not taking midodrine due to inability to take POs. His vital signs are stable, but he has hypernatremia, acute pain, respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, peritonitis, and anemia. He has chronic thrombocytopenia, cirrhosis, and hepatitis. His lab results show elevated WBC, Hct, and Cr, with low albumin and Ca++ levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia is likely multifactorial, caused by low-grade hemolysis, potassium infusion in TPN, and aldactone therapy. Giving lasix and NaHCO3 may help correct the electrolyte imbalance.
2. Hemolysis: The patient's hemolysis is likely due to burr cell hemolysis from cirrhosis. Monitoring of lab results and treatment with blood transfusions may be necessary.
3. HOTN: The patient's hot flushes are likely due to not taking midodrine. Encouraging the patient to take midodrine as prescribed may help alleviate this symptom.
4. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy is likely due to toxic metabolic causes, and treatment with PO lactulose, FFP, and cryo may be necessary. Placement of an NGT may also be considered.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium is atypical for hepatic encephalopathy and may be due to toxic metabolic causes. Monitoring of lab results and treatment with medications may be necessary to manage this symptom.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to sepsis and may require mechanical ventilation.
7. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to Clostridium perfringens infection and may require antibiotics and source control measures.
8. Peritonitis: The patient's peritonitis is likely due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and may require antibiotics and source control measures.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic blood loss and may require blood transfusions.
10. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due to chronic liver disease and may require platelet transfusions.

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: TPN with lipids at 77 mL/hour
* Glycemic Control: Monitor blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as necessary
* Lines: Multi-lumen and arterial lines in place
* Prophylaxis: DVT boots, stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI, and VAP precautions
* Disposition: ICU care continues

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Hyperkalemia:  Cause is likely multi-factorial, including hemolysis,
   increased retention [**2-9**] spironolactone, and decreased stool output
   (though still substantial) [**2-9**] not being given po lactulose, and ARF
   ([**2-9**] ATN, hypotension). s/p calcium gluconate, Kayexalate, lasix,
   D50/insulin, sodium bicarb.
   - continue CVVH
   - appreciate renal recs
   - q6h lyte checks with CVVH
   .
   Sepsis/leukocytosis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also
   possibly due to pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors
   and IVF bolus to support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so
   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   Octreotide discontinued per hepatology.  Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda
   12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin. Hypotensive on
   [**12-27**]
 required pressor support x3; started vanc/zosyn/flagyl for
   broad-spectrum coverage. s/p diagnostic para on [**12-27**]
 70 polys.
   Lactate elevated.
   - Continue vanco/zosyn/flagyl for broad coverage
   - Continue Midodrine
   - Continue neo, levo, vasopressin for MAP >65.
   - monitor fever curve, low-grade temps, tachycardia
   - f/u CT torso final read
   .
   Peritonitis: ?SBP but without positive cultures.  Abdominal pain,
   prominent neutrophilia on ascitic fluid diff (17,000 WBC, 87% neuts)
   and significant left-shift on CBC with diff (33% bands) in the setting
   of a history of variceal bleeding are all consistent with SBP. Normally
   would treat with ceftriaxone, but given additional concerns for
   pneumonia will treat with cipro, pip-tazo and vancomycin. Hepatobiliary
   sx recs ([**12-15**]): recommend re-tapping him today.  If his WBC is still
   very high, he may need to be explored.  Leukocytosis, hypotension, s/p
   diagnostic para on [**12-27**].

   - f/u CT torso read
   .
   Dyspnea/Respiratory Failure: Pt was intubated in the ED given
   hypotension, concern for developing respiratory failure given
   tachypnea. ABG in MICU indicates elevated PaO2 on current ventilator
   settings.  The differential for the pt's dyspnea includes pneumonia,
   influenza, ascites or CHF. The pt had a left shift on CBC with diff and
   his girlfriend reported that he recently had a "respiratory infection"
   which raises concern for a post-viral pna or bacterial pna. Initial
   read of CXR raised concern for R LL infiltrate, however on final read
   there is no mention of an opacity. Tachypnea likely secondary to
   acidosis.  Also evidence of volume overload and CHF given edema, CXR
   consistent with fluid overload, and elevated CVP. All sedation off
   since [**12-19**].  Extubated with significantly improved respiratory status.
   Then incr work of breathing, AMS, pressor requirement, hypercarbia, so
   intubated on [**12-27**].
   - noon ABG
   - daily lactate
   - hold on diuresis today
   - vanc/zosyn/flagyl
   - appears to need PEEP, wean FiO2 as tolerated
   - CVVH
   .
   Altered mental status: Pt is still with decreased mental status despite
   being off of sedation x 1 day on [**12-19**]. Neurologic exam difficult, but
   no obvious deficit. The most likely etiology at this point is stage 4

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and hyponatremia. He was admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, and was found to have peritonitis and a possibility of CAP. He has been diagnosed with sepsis, acute pain, respiratory failure, peritonitis, and anemia. He is currently intubated and on pressors, and has a history of variceal bleeding and liver disease.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (18.3)
* Elevated creatinine (1.5)
* Elevated bilirubin (18)
* Elevated lactate (6.6 mmol/L)
* Elevated alkaline phosphatase (208 U/L)
* Elevated aspartate transaminase (796 U/L)
* Elevated alanine transaminase (796 U/L)
* Thrombocytopenia (34)
* Hypocalcemia (Ca++ 10.5 mg/dL)
* Hyperkalemia (17 mEq/L)

The patient's medications include:

* Midodrine
* Kayexalate
* Lactulose
* Vasopressin
* Norepinephrine
* Phenylephrine
* Calcium gluconate
* Furosemide
* Pantoprazole
* Octreotide
* Tamoxifen

The patient's medical issues include:

* Hypernatremia
* Hyponatremia
* Acute pain
* Respiratory failure
* Peritonitis
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hepatitis C cirrhosis
* Liver disease
* Gynecomastia
* Epistaxis
* Thrombocytopenia
* Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue CVVH
* Continue antibiotics
* Continue pressors
* Monitor urine output closely
* Monitor lactate levels
* Monitor bilirubin levels
* Monitor platelet count
* Monitor electrolyte levels
* Consider head CT if AMS persists
* Consider re-tapping of ascites if WBC count remains high
* Consider liver transplant if patient's condition does not improve

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Respiratory failure
* Peritonitis
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hepatitis C cirrhosis
* Liver disease
* Gynecomastia
* Epistaxis
* Thrombocytopenia
* Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent these potential complications from arising.

   60 year old man with history of hepatitis C (s/p interferon rx with no
   response), cirrhosis, esophageal varices and hyponatremia admitted with
   dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain, found to have peritonitis as well
   as a possibility of CAP.
   .
   Patient is critically ill
 concern for intraabdominal pathology
   resulting in hypotension/sepsis/lactic acidosis/respiratory failure. On
   3 pressors, still hypotensive. Hyperkalemic, getting CVVH. Family in
   process of being notified. Believe peritonitis or bowel ischemia to be
   causative, or acalculous cholecystitis or aspiration pneumonia. ARF
   with precipitous decr UO yesterday. Intubated.
   .
   Hyperkalemia:  Cause is likely multi-factorial, including hemolysis,
   increased retention [**2-9**] spironolactone, and decreased stool output
   (though still substantial) [**2-9**] not being given po lactulose, and ARF
   ([**2-9**] ATN, hypotension). s/p calcium gluconate, Kayexalate, lasix,
   D50/insulin, sodium bicarb. Etiology -?cell lysis, ?ARF.
   - continue CVVH
   - appreciate renal recs
   - q6h lyte checks with CVVH
   .
   Sepsis/leukocytosis: Suspect sepsis is due to SBP as below, also
   possibly due to pna. Will treat with abx as outlined below, pressors
   and IVF bolus to support BP. Mixed venous O2 sat in ED was 91%, so
   pRBCs were not administered, however hematocrit on admission was ~21,
   and pt was transfused. Hypothermia (current temp 95 with bear hugger),
   hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and hypoglycemia consistent with sepsis, but
   also concerning for adrenal insufficiency. Pt has not recently been on
   steroids and has no other RF for adrenal insufficiency.  BCx grew
   Clostridium Perfringens [**12-13**].  d/c
ed cisatracurium. s/p CT abdomen on
   [**12-17**].  Pressors off as of [**12-20**].  Steroids dc
ed as of [**12-21**].
   Octreotide discontinued per hepatology.  Switched Zosyn to Cipro/Clinda
   12/15 per ID recs; dc
ed Vanc, Clindamycin, Micafungin. Hypotensive on
   [**12-27**]
 required pressor support x3; started vanc/zosyn/flagyl for
   broad-spectrum coverage. s/p diagnostic para on [**12-27**]
 70% polys =
   peritonitis. Lactate elevated.

   - Check vanco dosing

   - f/u CT torso read
   - Give stress steroids, hydrocortisone 50 IV q6h

   Then incr work of breathing, AMS, pressor requirement, hypercarbia, so

**Summary:**

The patient is a 60-year-old male admitted with dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. He has a history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis, and esophageal varices. The patient was intubated in the emergency department due to hypotension and concern for developing respiratory failure. He was diagnosed with sepsis, peritonitis, and acute renal failure. The patient's condition has deteriorated, and he is currently in the ICU with a high level of care.

**Medical Complications:**

1. **Hyperkalemia:** The patient's potassium levels are elevated, likely due to a combination of factors including hemolysis, increased retention of potassium, and decreased stool output.
2. **Acute Renal Failure (ARF):** The patient's creatinine levels have been rising, and he has developed oliguria. The likely causes are sepsis, hypotension, and intra-abdominal pressure.
3. **Sepsis:** The patient has developed sepsis, likely due to peritonitis and possibly pneumonia.
4. **Peritonitis:** The patient has peritonitis, which is likely secondary to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
5. **Hepatic Encephalopathy:** The patient's altered mental status is likely due to stage 4 hepatic encephalopathy.
6. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's platelet count is low, likely due to poor synthetic function in the setting of liver disease.
7. **Acidosis:** The patient has developed metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactic acidosis in the setting of sepsis and SBP.

**Assessment and Plan:**

1. Continue CVVH to manage hyperkalemia and ARF.
2. Treat sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl.
3. Manage peritonitis with antibiotics and consider re-tapping the patient.
4. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider head CT and additional work-up if necessary.
5. Continue IV PPI and consider fentanyl or propofol for pain management.
6. Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider platelet transfusions as necessary.
7. Consider stress steroids and hydrocortisone to manage adrenal insufficiency.

**Concerns:**

1. The patient's condition is critical, and he requires a high level of care.
2. The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires close monitoring.
3. The patient's renal function is deteriorating, and he requires close monitoring and management.
4. The patient's liver function is compromised, and he requires close monitoring and management.
5. The patient's mental status is altered, and he requires close monitoring and management.

**Future Plans:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis and peritonitis.
3. Consider re-tapping the patient to manage peritonitis.
4. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider additional work-up if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's acidosis and consider alkali therapy if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-inch tall, 100.6 kg male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of acute liver failure, sepsis, and respiratory failure. The patient has been intubated and is receiving invasive ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.1°C (97°F)
* Heart rate: 81 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 60/37 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 29 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 93%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) 25 mmHg, pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) not available

The patient has undergone several procedures, including:

* Paracentesis: 900 mL of ascitic fluid was drained
* Dialysis catheter insertion: [**2150-12-28**] 02:00 AM
* Invasive ventilation: started [**2150-12-27**] 08:00 PM

The patient's laboratory results are:

* Blood cultures: positive for bacteria
* Urine culture: pending
* Complete blood count (CBC): white blood cell count (WBC) 18.3 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) 7.5 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) 79 K/uL
* Liver function tests (LFTs): aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 208 IU/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 796 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase (ALK) 97 IU/L
* Renal function tests (RFTs): creatinine (Cr) 1.0 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 17 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: sodium (Na) 141 mEq/L, potassium (K) 6.8 mEq/L, chloride (Cl) 79 mg/dL, bicarbonate (HCO3) 26.0%

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Acute pain
* Respiratory failure (acute, not ARDS)
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Peritonitis (spontaneous bacterial)
* Anemia (chronic and acute secondary to blood loss)
* Thrombocytopenia (chronic)
* Renal failure (acute)
* Cirrhosis of the liver (other)
* Hepatitis (other)
* Metabolic acidosis

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Maintenance of invasive ventilation and dialysis
* Management of hypernatremia and metabolic acidosis
* Treatment of sepsis and peritonitis
* Management of anemia and thrombocytopenia
* Renal replacement therapy (RRT) as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of respiratory function
* Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Worsening of sepsis and peritonitis
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Development of acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Increased risk of infection due to invasive devices
* Development of hepatic encephalopathy
* Increased risk of bleeding due to liver failure

The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is ICU care.
